text: I'm rod nordland a correspondent for the

she's a 19 year old mother who was quite

was suffering from acute malnutrition
she came here to the Indira Gandhi
pediatric hospital in Kabul from her

malnourished and has a condition known
as kashyyk or something most commonly
associated with African famines it's a
condition where the child's hair turns
orange and the belly descends the
condition can be reversible and this
child was probably caught in time
much to our surprise we've discovered
that throughout Afghanistan particularly
in conflict areas there is what doctors

that the patient is in danger of dying

it's a dramatically growing problem
especially prevalent in areas like
Helmand and Kandahar although just how
prevalent is a contentious and
politically sensitive issue when UNICEF
issued a report saying that more than
half of Afghan kids were malnourished
and as many as 17 percent in some
provinces acutely malnourished the
government was infuriated and UNICEF
repudiated its own report such levels
would indicate a serious health
emergency
so now UNICEF and the Afghan government
are cooperating in a new more extensive
survey judging from the experts and
doctors we spoke to that is also likely
to show a very bad situation
both health care workers and parents
really don't understand why this is
happening it's not like there's a famine
here it's the result of bad health
practices dislocation because of war
which is preventing people from getting
to clinics mothers who prefer formula to
breastfeeding formula made with tainted
water it doesn't seem to be because of
insufficient food supplies it's an
extremely complex problem and one that
does seem to be getting worse not better
in the hospitals we visited there was
evidence of unexpected shortages in
therapeutic foods which are used to
treat malnutrition specifically two
kinds of milk called f75 and f-100 used
for the youngest and most malnourished
children then when kids get strong
enough a solid food called Plumpy'nut
UNICEF provides enough therapeutic food
to reach 50,000 kids in hospitals around
the country nonetheless we kept finding
places where there shortages UNICEF says
this is due to supply chain issues and
they are working hard to fix the problem
